metadata.titleEn: Geochemical element parameter datasett of a representative permafrost  wetland in the mid-late Holocene in the headwater area of the Yellow River (HAYR)
metadata.description: The Maduo Xiang (Maduo Village) permafrost wetland profile (35°02′24″ N, 96°15′36″ E, 4490 m) was located on a south slope, ca. 10 km from Maduo Xiang (Maduo Village), in the northwestern HAYR in the north of Bayan Har Mountains. Geochemical element content were carried out using an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (Magix PW2403, the Netherlands), with an estimated error of less than 0.3% for geochemical elements. Reconstructions of the Holocene (especially the mid-Holocene) climatic and environmental changes may serve as an analogue for future scenarios.
metadata.instructions: Representative data of the Geochemical elements in text format storage, the name of the file for "element Geochemical content. TXT".Data read method: the data set all of the ASCII file can be directly opened by text program (like notepad).In addition to the header file, the main content for s and element content of numerical representation.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of geochemical element parameters used in studying Holocene soil weathering and climate change in permafrost wetlands?
Feature Specification.Answer: 0.3% measurement error, changes in soil chemical weathering, reflect regional climate changes

Quantification.Question: What is the measurement error associated with the geochemical element content in the soil sediments using the X-ray fluorescence spectrometer method?

Definition.Question: What is a geochemical element parameter dataset in the context of permafrost wetlands?
Definition.Answer: A geochemical element parameter dataset in the context of permafrost wetlands refers to a collection of data that includes the concentrations and ratios of geochemical elements within soil sediments from permafrost wetlands. This dataset is used to indicate changes in soil chemical weathering processes over time, which can further reflect regional climate changes since approximately 7000 years before present (B.P.). Such a dataset is typically derived from soil core samples and analyzed using techniques like X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy to measure element concentrations with a specified error margin.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying factors that contribute to the variability in geochemical element parameters in permafrost wetlands over the mid-to-late Holocene?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variability in geochemical element parameters in permafrost wetlands over the mid-to-late Holocene is influenced by changes in soil chemical weathering and regional climate variations since approximately 7000 years B.P. Such changes can be identified through the analysis of geochemical element content and their ratios, which provide insights into historical climate and environmental shifts in the Yellow River source region.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes on understanding regional climate change if a dataset uses X-ray fluorescence spectrometry to analyze geochemical element content in permafrost wetland profiles?
Causal Consequence.Answer: By using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry to analyze geochemical element content, researchers can track changes in soil chemical weathering processes over approximately 7000 years. This can provide insights into historical regional climate changes and offer valuable context for predicting future climate and environmental shifts in the Yellow River source area.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to measure and analyze geochemical element concentrations in soil sediments for assessing historical climate changes in permafrost wetlands?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Geochemical element concentrations in soil sediments are measured using an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (Magix PW2403, Netherlands) with a measurement error of 0.3%. The data are used to analyze the changes in geochemical element content and ratios, which indicate soil chemical weathering variations and reflect regional climate changes since approximately 7000 years before present.
